awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Biomechanics of the Pericellular Matrix of Fibrous Tissues
awd_abstract_narration:
The cells in cartilage and other soft tissues are surrounded by a soft matrix of molecules that the cells produce. The response of a cell to mechanical loading depends on the mechanical properties of this matrix.  If it is soft or stiff will change whether the cell is protected from mechanical loadings or whether it is not.  The mechanical loads on cells are known to modify the cell's production of matrix molecules and also to change how fast the cell produces repair molecules for cartilage. The matrix, therefore, helps to control how loads on cartilage (or other soft tissues) change the cell activity.  This effect of the matrix will be analyzed in this Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) research project.  Education and outreach activities will be integrated with the research. A new course will be developed to increase the learning of biomechanics and nanotechnology for students at Drexel. The PI will give workshops on biomechanics for Philadelphia inner city high school teachers and students, and develop a science museum exhibition display with the structure-mechanics of connective tissues as the focus. The research will add knowledge of how mechanical loading effects cartilage metabolism, a key part of understanding and preventing cartilage diseases such as osteoarthritis.

This research will generate new knowledge on the biomechanics of the pericellular matrix (PCM) of fibrous tissues, to advance the understanding of fibrous tissue cell mechanotransduction. The fibrous tissue PCM is composed of porous collagen fibril network and proteoglycans (PGs). We hypothesize that this specialized PCM can attenuate cell strain under tension, and this function is mediated by its glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) on the PGs and the collagen fibril network. Using murine meniscus fibrous outer zone as the model tissue, we will test this hypothesis in two specific aims. In aim 1, we will test if removal of GAGs of the PCM reduces its compressive modulus, and thus, increases ECM-cell strain transmission and alters cell calcium signaling and metabolism under tension. In aim 2, we will alter the PCM collagen fibril structure by reducing the expression of collagen V in mice. We will test if loss of collagen V increases the PCM fibril alignment, and thus, cell strain transmission. These results will reveal the contribution of GAGs and collagen fibrils to the function of PCM in mediating cell mechanotransduction, achieving our overall goal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Fibrocartilage is a family of connective tissues that withstand a complex array of tensile, shear and compressive stresses in vivo. Degeneration of fibrocartilage is associated with many diseases such as post-traumatic osteoarthritis, disc hernia temporomandibular joint disorder and psoriatic arthritis. In fibrocartilage, cells inhabit a structurally distinctive microdomain, known as the “pericellular matrix” (PCM), which plays a pivotal role in mediating the initial assembly of the extracellular matrix (ECM) and reciprocal cell-matrix mechanosensing. To date, there is little knowledge of the biomechanics and mechanobiological functions of the PCM in fibrocartilage. The objective of this project was to elucidate the molecular activities that govern the structure-mechanics principles of fibrocartilage PCM, as well as its mechanobiological function in regulating the resident cells.

With the support of this NSF grant, we have shown that the fibrocartilage PCM comprises randomly oriented collagen fibrils forming a 3D basket with a high concentration of proteoglycans and their sulfated glycosaminoglycans (sGAGs). This contrasts sharply with the bulk ECM, which is characterized by well-aligned, densely packed collagen fibers with little proteoglycan content. Using murine meniscus as the model tissue, we quantified the elastic and viscoelastic micromechanics of the PCM via immunofluorescence (IF)-guided atomic force microscopy (AFM) nanomechanical mapping. Results highlighted the distinct mechanical properties of the PCM compared to the fibrous ECM, including lower elastic and viscoelastic moduli, shorter relaxation time constants and salient mechanical isotropy. We further showed that sGAGs are a crucial determinant of the PCM micromechanics, as enzymatic sGAG removal resulted in significantly reduced moduli and long-term relaxation time constant. Conversely, sGAG removal had only a minor impact on the intracellular calcium signaling activities of resident meniscal cells. This stands in contrast to the pronounced impact of sGAGs in mediating the calcium responses of articular cartilage chondrocytes, underscoring the distinct mechanosensing mechanisms of fibrocartilage versus hyaline cartilage cells. Next, studying the murine model with collagen V deficiency, we demonstrated the pivotal regulatory role of collagen V, a minor fibril-forming collagen, in the integrity and function of meniscus PCM. Reduction of collagen V resulted in significantly disrupted PCM fibrillar architecture, as marked by an increase in collagen fibril diameter, alignment and heterogeneity. These changes led to reduced tissue moduli and relaxation time constants, as well as increased mechanical anisotropy. In turn, resident meniscal cells exhibited significantly reduced in situ calcium signaling activities and showed altered expressions of matrix genes, including lysyl oxidase (LOX) and tenascin-C. We then validated these reciprocal responses in vitro, where collagen V-deficient meniscal cells expressed higher levels of LOX and tenascin-C but synthesized weakened nascent PCM with impaired strain-shielding function for cells under applied tensile stretch. Together, these findings emphasize the critical role of PCM in fibrocartilage mechanobiology and suggest targeting it could enhance treatments for meniscal and other fibrocartilaginous tissue diseases. This research has broader impacts on musculoskeletal-related public healthcare, as the outcomes have established a foundation for developing new tissue regeneration strategies based on the modulation of the PCM and its molecular constituents. In addition, understanding the role of collagen V will provide new insights into the care of patients with classic Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (cEDS), a heritable genetic disease caused by mutations or haploinsufficiency of collagen V.

This award has broader impacts in education and outreach. Three Ph.D. candidates and two undergraduate students at Drexel University received training while working on this project. Special efforts were made to recruit and retain students from underrepresented groups in engineering, including women and minorities. The research findings of this project have been incorporated in the curricula at Drexel University, benefiting both undergraduate and graduate teaching. This includes supervising undergraduate teams for their senior design projects to design new engineering products for biomechanics and biomaterials research as the capstone of their undergraduate education. Additionally, the PI collaborated with inner-city high schools in Philadelphia to provide annual science workshops, aiming to increase the students' enthusiasm for STEM careers. The PI has also participated in Drexel's BIOMED Summer Academy to engage high school students in a strategically chosen curriculum activities during summer break. The results from the project have also been broadly disseminated to the academic community and general public through journal publications, local and national workshops, conferences, and social media.
